title: 104_hr732
content: The amendment to Section 315 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 limits contributions from non-local individuals to candidates for the House of Representatives. Candidates cannot accept contributions exceeding 50% from non-local individuals in their district or exceeding 10% from non-local individuals in their state. SEC. 2 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to reduce the contribution limit from multicandidate political committees to House of Representatives candidates to $1,000. SEC. 3 introduces a ban on soft money in political activities. Sec. 323 imposes limitations and reporting requirements on payments for mixed political activities by national or state political party committees. These payments must come from an account subject to the Act's requirements. Mixed political activities are defined as those aimed at influencing federal elections but also serve other purposes. Repeal of Building Fund Exception to the Definition of the Term "Contribution" under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 by amending Section 301(8)(B) to remove clause (viii) and redesignate clauses (ix) through (xiv) as clauses (viii) through (xiii). SEC. 4 amends the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act to reduce the official mail allowance formula. SEC. 5 prohibits unsolicited mail as franked mail within 60 days before a member's primary and general election. Section 3210(a)(6) of title 39, United States Code is amended to replace "mass mailing" with "unsolicited mailing" and define "unsolicited mailing" as all mail except for specific exemptions. The amendments made by subsection (a) regarding the duties of the Member of Congress will apply to sessions of Congress starting after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. Disclosure of member's first class mailings to the public, including costs related to franked, first class mass mailings. Effective date applies to sessions of Congress after enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. Amendments to Communications Act of 1934. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to reduce the time period for lowest charge of a broadcasting station for political candidates. A licensee cannot preempt the use of a broadcasting station by a legally qualified candidate for public office during specified periods. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to reduce the time period for lowest charge of a broadcasting station for political candidates. A candidate's advertising spot may be preempted if a program is preempted due to circumstances beyond the station's control. The time period for lowest charge of a broadcasting station for political candidates is reduced. Preemption of a candidate's advertising spot may occur if a program is preempted due to circumstances beyond the station's control. SEC. 8 prohibits House of Representatives members, officers, and employees from traveling at the expense of lobbyists. The term "Member of the House of Representatives" is defined in this section.
